user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 1.2 is: Language extensions should not be used.
You should report only when the code uses any language compiler extensions that are explicitly stated as an extension in compiler documentations.
</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of check_uri_match:
```c
static bool
check_uri_match (struct MHD_Connection *connection, char *uri, size_t uri_len)
{
  char *qmark;
  char *args;
  struct MHD_Daemon *const daemon = connection->daemon;

  uri[uri_len] = 0;
  qmark = memchr (uri,
                  '?',
                  uri_len);
  if (NULL != qmark)
    *qmark = '\0';

  /* Need to unescape URI before comparing with connection->url */
  uri_len = daemon->unescape_callback (daemon->unescape_callback_cls,
                                       connection,
                                       uri);
  if ((uri_len != connection->rq.url_len) ||
      (0 != memcmp (uri, connection->rq.url, uri_len)))
  {
#ifdef HAVE_MESSAGES
    MHD_DLOG (daemon,
              _ ("Authentication failed, URI does not match.\n"));
#endif
    return false;
  }

  args = (NULL != qmark) ? (qmark + 1) : uri + uri_len;

  if (! check_argument_match (connection,
                              args) )
  {
#ifdef HAVE_MESSAGES
    MHD_DLOG (daemon,
              _ ("Authentication failed, arguments do not match.\n"));
#endif
    return false;
  }
  return true;
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are related to the target function check_uri_match:
void
MHD_DLOG (const struct MHD_Daemon *daemon,
          const char *format,
          ...)
{
  va_list va;

  if (0 == (daemon->options & MHD_USE_ERROR_LOG))
    return;
  va_start (va, format);
  daemon->custom_error_log (daemon->custom_error_log_cls,
                            format,
                            va);
  va_end (va);
}
</additional code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation: I inspected the provided functions for compiler/language extensions that are explicitly documented as extensions (e.g. GCC nested functions, statement-expressions ({ ... }), typeof, __attribute__, __asm__, __builtin_*, labels-as-values, anonymous structs/unions beyond standard, thread-local __thread, nonstandard inline keywords, or other vendor-specific keywords). None of those appear in the provided code. The code only uses standard C features: pointer and const qualifiers, standard library functions (memchr, memcmp), size_t, NULL, standard variadic handling (va_list, va_start/va_end), preprocessor conditionals (#ifdef) and macros (MHD_DLOG, _()) which are normal portable constructs or macros defined elsewhere. Therefore there are no explicit compiler language extensions in these fragments to report for MISRA C 2023 Rule 1.2.
